1# -*- coding: utf-8 -*- 

2 

3"""Primary wepy simulation database driver and access API using the 

4HDF5 format. 

5 

6The HDF5 Format Specification 

7============================= 

8 

9As part of the wepy framework this module provides a fully-featured 

10API for creating and accessing data generated in weighted ensemble 

11simulations run with wepy. 

12 

13The need for a special purpose format is many-fold but primarily it is 

14the nonlinear branching structure of walker trajectories coupled with 

15weights. 

16 

17That is for standard simulations data is organized as independent 

18linear trajectories of frames each related linearly to the one before 

19it and after it. 

20 

21In weighted ensemble due to the resampling (i.e. cloning and merging) 

22of walkers, a single frame may have multiple 'child' frames. 

23 

24This is the primary motivation for this format. 

25 

26However, in practice it solves several other issues and itself is a 

27more general and flexible format than for just weighted ensemble 

28simulations. 

29 

30Concretely the WepyHDF5 format is simply an informally described 

31schema that is commensurable with the HDF5 constructs of hierarchical 

32groups (similar to unix filesystem directories) arranged as a tree 

33with datasets as the leaves. 

34 

35The hierarchy is fairly deep and so we will progress downwards from 

36the top and describe each broad section in turn breaking it down when 

37necessary. 

38 

39Header 

40------ 

41 

42The items right under the root of the tree are: 

43 

44- runs 

45- topology 

46- _settings 

47 

48The first item 'runs' is itself a group that contains all of the 

49primary data from simulations. In WepyHDF5 the run is the unit 

50dataset. All data internal to a run is self contained. That is for 

51multiple dependent trajectories (e.g. from cloning and merging) all 

52exist within a single run. 

53 

54This excludes metadata-like things that may be needed for interpreting 

55this data, such as the molecular topology that imposes structure over 

56a frame of atom positions. This information is placed in the 

57'topology' item. 

58 

59The topology field has no specified internal structure at this 

60time. However, with the current implementation of the WepyHDF5Reporter 

61(which is the principal implementation of generating a WepyHDF5 

62object/file from simulations) this is simply a string dataset. This 

63string dataset should be a JSON compliant string. The format of which 

64is specified elsewhere and was borrowed from the mdtraj library. 

65 

66Warning! this format and specification for the topology is subject to 

67change in the future and will likely be kept unspecified indefinitely. 

68 

69For most intents and purposes (which we assume to be for molecular or 

70molecular-like simulations) the 'topology' item (and perhaps any other 

71item at the top level other than those proceeded by and underscore, 

72such as in the '_settings' item) is merely useful metadata that 

73applies to ALL runs and is not dynamical. 

74 

75In the language of the orchestration module all data in 'runs' uses 

76the same 'apparatus' which is the function that takes in the initial 

77conditions for walkers and produces new walkers. The apparatus may 

78differ in the specific values of parameters but not in kind. This is 

79to facilitate runs that are continuations of other runs. For these 

80kinds of simulations the state of the resampler, boundary conditions, 

81etc. will not be as they were initially but are the same in kind or 

82type. 

83 

84All of the necessary type information of data in runs is kept in the 

85'_settings' group. This is used to serialize information about the 

86data types, shapes, run to run continuations etc. This allows for the 

87initialization of an empty (no runs) WepyHDF5 database at one time and 

88filling of data at another time. Otherwise types of datasets would 

89have to be inferred from the data itself, which may not exist yet. 

90 

91As a convention items which are preceeded by an underscore (following 

92the python convention) are to be considered hidden and mechanical to 

93the proper functioning of various WepyHDF5 API features, such as 

94sparse trajectory fields. 

95 

96The '_settings' is specified as a simple key-value structure, however 

97values may be arbitrarily complex. 

98 

99Runs 

100---- 

101 

102The meat of the format is contained within the runs group: 

103 

104- runs 

105 

106 - 0 

107 - 1 

108 - 2 

109 - ... 

110 

111Under the runs group are a series of groups for each run. Runs are 

112named according to the order in which they were added to the database. 

113 

114Within a run (say '0' from above) we have a number of items: 

115 

116- 0 

117 

118 - init_walkers 

119 - trajectories 

120 - decision 

121 - resampling 

122 - resampler 

123 - warping 

124 - progress 

125 - boundary_conditions 

126 

127Trajectories 

128^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

129 

130The 'trajectories' group is where the data for the frames of the 

131walker trajectories is stored. 

132 

133Even though the tree-like trajectories of weighted ensemble data may 

134be well suited to having a tree-like storage topology we have opted to 

135use something more familiar to the field, and have used a collection 

136of linear "trajectories". 

137 

138This way of breaking up the trajectory data coupled with proper 

139records of resampling (see below) allows for the imposition of a tree 

140structure without committing to that as the data storage topology. 

141 

142This allows the WepyHDF5 format to be easily used as a container 

143format for collections of linear trajectories. While this is not 

144supported in any real capacity it is one small step to convergence. We 

145feel that a format that contains multiple trajectories is important 

146for situations like weighted ensemble where trajectories are 

147interdependent. The transition to a storage format like HDF5 however 

148opens up many possibilities for new features for trajectories that 

149have not occurred despite several attempts to forge new formats based 

150on HDF5 (TODO: get references right; see work in mdtraj and MDHDF5). 

151 

152Perhaps these formats have not caught on because the existing formats 

153(e.g. XTC, DCD) for simple linear trajectories are good enough and 

154there is little motivation to migrate. 

155 

156However, by making the WepyHDF5 format (and related sub-formats to be 

157described e.g. record groups and the trajectory format) both cover a 

158new use case which can't be achieved with old formats and old ones 

159with ease. 

160 

161Once users see the power of using a format like HDF5 from using wepy 

162they may continue to use it for simpler simulations. 

163 

164 

165In any case the 'trajectories' in the group for weighted ensemble 

166simulations should be thought of only as containers and not literally 

167as trajectories. That is frame 4 does not necessarily follow from 

168frame 3. So one may think of them more as "lanes" or "slots" for 

169trajectory data that needs to be stitched together with the 

170appropriate resampling records. 

171 

172The routines and methods for generating contiguous trajectories from 

173the data in WepyHDF5 are given through the 'analysis' module, which 

174generates "traces" through the dataset. 

175 

176With this in mind we will describe the sub-format of a trajectory now. 

177 

178The 'trajectories' group is similar to the 'runs' group in that it has 

179sub-groups whose names are numbers. These numbers however are not the 

180order in which they are created but an index of that trajectory which 

181are typically laid out all at once. 

182 

183For a wepy simulation with a constant number of walkers you will only 

184ever need as many trajectories/slots as there are walkers. So if you 

185have 8 walkers then you will have trajectories 0 through 7. Concretely: 

186 

187- runs 

188 

189 - 0 

190 

191 - trajectories 

192 

193 - 0 

194 - 1 

195 - 2 

196 - 3 

197 - 4 

198 - 5 

199 - 6 

200 - 7 

201 

202If we look at trajectory 0 we might see the following groups within: 

203 

204- positions 

205- box_vectors 

206- velocities 

207- weights 

208 

209Which is what you would expect for a constant pressure molecular 

210dynamics simulation where you have the positions of the atoms, the box 

211size, and velocities of the atoms. 

212 

213The particulars for what "fields" a trajectory in general has are not 

214important but this important use-case is directly supported in the 

215WepyHDF5 format. 

216 

217In any such simulation, however, the 'weights' field will appear since 

218this is the weight of the walker of this frame and is a value 

219important to weighted ensemble and not the underlying dynamics. 

220 

221The naive approach to these fields is that each is a dataset of 

222dimension (n_frames, feature_vector_shape[0], ...) where the first dimension 

223is the cycle_idx and the rest of the dimensions are determined by the 

224atomic feature vector for each field for a single frame. 

225 

226For example, the positions for a molecular simulation with 100 atoms 

227with x, y, and z coordinates that ran for 1000 cycles would be a 

228dataset of the shape (1000, 100, 3). Similarly the box vectors would 

229be (1000, 3, 3) and the weights would be (1000, 1). 

230 

231This uniformity vastly simplifies accessing and adding new variables 

232and requires that individual state values in walkers always be arrays 

233with shapes, even when they are single values (e.g. energy). The 

234exception being the weight which is handled separately. 

235 

236However, this situation is actually more complex to allow for special 

237features. 

238 

239First of all is the presence of compound fields which allow nesting of 

240multiple groups. 

241 

242The above "trajectory fields" would have identifiers such as the 

243literal strings 'positions' and 'box_vectors', while a compound field 

244would have an identifier 'observables/rmsd' or 'alt_reps/binding_site'. 

245 

246Use of trajectory field names using the '/' path separator will 

247automatically make a field a group and the last element of the field 

248name the dataset. So for the observables example we might have: 

249 

250- 0 

251 

252 - observables 

253 

254 - rmsd 

255 - sasa 

256 

257Where the rmsd would be accessed as a trajectory field of trajectory 0 

258as 'observables/rmsd' and the solvent accessible surface area as 

259'observables/sasa'. 

260 

261This example introduces how the WepyHDF5 format is not only useful for 

262storing data produced by simulation but also in the analysis of that 

263data and computation of by-frame quantities. 

264 

265The 'observables' compound group key prefix is special and will be 

266used in the 'compute_observables' method. 

267 

268The other special compound group key prefix is 'alt_reps' which is 

269used for particle simulations to store "alternate representation" of 

270the positions. This is useful in cooperation with the next feature of 

271wepy trajectory fields to allow for more economical storage of data. 

272 

273The next feature (and complication of the format) is the allowance for 

274sparse fields. As the fields were introduced we said that they should 

275have as many feature vectors as there are frames for the 

276simulation. In the example however, you will notice that storing both 

277the full atomic positions and velocities for a long simulation 

278requires a heavy storage burden. 

279 

280So perhaps you only want to store the velocities (or forces) every 100 

281frames so that you can be able to restart a simulation form midway 

282through the simulation. This is achieved through sparse fields. 

283 

284A sparse field is no longer a dataset but a group with two items: 

285 

286- _sparse_idxs 

287- data 

288 

289The '_sparse_idxs' are simply a dataset of integers that assign each 

290element of the 'data' dataset to a frame index. Using the above 

291example we run a simulation for 1000 frames with 100 atoms and we save 

292the velocities every 100 frames we would have a 'velocities/data' 

293dataset of shape (100, 100, 3) which is 10 times less data than if it 

294were saved every frame. 

295 

296While this complicates the storage format use of the proper API 

297methods should be transparent whether you are returning a sparse field 

298or not. 

299 

300As alluded to above the use of sparse fields can be used for more than 

301just accessory fields. In many simulations, such as those with full 

302atomistic simulations of proteins in solvent we often don't care about 

303the dynamics of most of the atoms in the simulation and so would like 

304to not have to save them. 

305 

306The 'alt_reps' compound field is meant to solve this. For example, the 

307WepyHDF5Reporter supports a special option to save only a subset of 

308the atoms in the main 'positions' field but also to save the full 

309atomic system as an alternate representation, which is the field name 

310'alt_reps/all_atoms'. So that you can still save the full system every 

311once in a while but be economical in what positions you save every 

312single frame. 

313 

314Note that there really isn't a way to achieve this with other 

315formats. You either make a completely new trajectory with only the 

316atoms of interest and now you are duplicating those in two places, or 

317you duplicate and then filter your full systems trajectory file and 

318rely on some sort of index to always live with it in the filesystem, 

319which is a very precarious scenario. The situation is particularly 

320hopeless for weighted ensemble trajectories. 

321 

322Init Walkers 

323^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

324 

325The data stored in the 'trajectories' section is the data that is 

326returned after running dynamics in a cycle. Since we view the WepyHDF5 

327as a completely self-contained format for simulations it seems 

328negligent to rely on outside sources (such as the filesystem) for the 

329initial structures that seeded the simulations. These states (and 

330weights) can be stored in this group. 

331 

332The format of this group is identical to the one for trajectories 

333except that there is only one frame for each slot and so the shape of 

334the datasets for each field is just the shape of the feature vector. 

335 

336Record Groups 

337^^^^^^^^^^^^^ 

338 

339TODO: add reference to reference groups 

340 

341The last five items are what are called 'record groups' and all follow 

342the same format. 

343 

344Each record group contains itself a number of datasets, where the 

345names of the datasets correspond to the 'field names' from the record 

346group specification. So each record groups is simply a key-value store 

347where the values must be datasets. 

348 

349For instance the fields in the 'resampling' (which is particularly 

350important as it encodes the branching structure) record group for a 

351WExplore resampler simulation are: 

352 

353- step_idx 

354- walker_idx 

355- decision_id 

356- target_idxs 

357- region_assignment 

358 

359Where the 'step_idx' is an integer specifying which step of resampling 

360within the cycle the resampling action took place (the cycle index is 

361metadata for the group). The 'walker_idx' is the index of the walker 

362that this action was assigned to. The 'decision_id' is an integer that 

363is related to an enumeration of decision types that encodes which 

364discrete action is to be taken for this resampling event (the 

365enumeration is in the 'decision' item of the run groups). The 

366'target_idxs' is a variable length 1-D array of integers which assigns 

367the results of the action to specific target 'slots' (which was 

368discussed for the 'trajectories' run group). And the 

369'region_assignment' is specific to WExplore which reports on which 

370region the walker was in at that time, and is a variable length 1-D 

371array of integers. 

372 

373Additionally, record groups are broken into two types: 

374 

375- continual 

376- sporadic 

377 

378Continual records occur once per cycle and so there is no extra 

379indexing necessary. 

380 

381Sporadic records can happen multiple or zero times per cycle and so 

382require a special index for them which is contained in the extra 

383dataset '_cycle_idxs'. 

384 

385It is worth noting that the underlying methods for each record group 

386are general. So while these are the official wepy record groups that 

387are supported if there is a use-case that demands a new record group 

388it is a fairly straightforward task from a developers perspective. 

389 

390"""

640# utility for paths 

641def _iter_field_paths(grp): 

642 """Return all subgroup field name paths from a group. 

643 

644 Useful for compound fields. For example if you have the group 

645 observables with multiple subfields: 

646 

647 - observables 

648 - rmsd 

649 - sasa 

650 

651 Passing the h5py group 'observables' will return the full field 

652 names for each subfield: 

653 

654 - 'observables/rmsd' 

655 - 'observables/sasa' 

656 

657 Parameters 

658 ---------- 

659 grp : h5py.Group 

660 The group to enumerate subfield names for. 

661 

662 Returns 

663 ------- 

664 subfield_names : list of str 

665 The full names for the subfields of the group. 

666 

667 """ 

668 field_paths = [] 

669 for field_name in grp: 

670 if isinstance(grp[field_name], h5py.Group): 

671 for subfield in grp[field_name]: 

672 

673 # if it is a sparse field don't do the subfields since 

674 # they will be _sparse_idxs and data which are not 

675 # what we want here 

676 if field_name not in grp.file['_settings/sparse_fields']: 

677 field_paths.append(field_name + '/' + subfield) 

678 else: 

679 field_paths.append(field_name) 

680 return field_paths 

681 

682class WepyHDF5(object): 

683 """Wrapper for h5py interface to an HDF5 file object for creation and 

684 access of WepyHDF5 data. 

685 

686 This is the primary implementation of the API for creating, 

687 accessing, and modifying data in an HDF5 file that conforms to the 

688 WepyHDF5 specification. 

689 

690 """ 

691 

692 MODES = ('r', 'r+', 'w', 'w-', 'x', 'a') 

693 """The recognized modes for opening the WepyHDF5 file.""" 

694 

695 WRITE_MODES = ('r+', 'w', 'w-', 'x', 'a') 

696 

697 

698 #### dunder methods 

699 

700 def __init__(self, filename, mode='x', 

701 topology=None, 

702 units=None, 

703 sparse_fields=None, 

704 feature_shapes=None, feature_dtypes=None, 

705 n_dims=None, 

706 alt_reps=None, main_rep_idxs=None, 

707 swmr_mode=False, 

708 expert_mode=False 

709 ): 

710 """Constructor for the WepyHDF5 class. 

711 

712 Initialize a new Wepy HDF5 file. This will create an h5py.File 

713 object. 

714 

715 The File will be closed after construction by default. 

716 

717 mode: 

718 r Readonly, file must exist 

719 r+ Read/write, file must exist 

720 w Create file, truncate if exists 

721 x or w- Create file, fail if exists 

722 a Read/write if exists, create otherwise 

723 

724 Parameters 

725 ---------- 

726 filename : str 

727 File path 

728 

729 mode : str 

730 Mode specification for opening the HDF5 file. 

731 

732 topology : str 

733 JSON string representing topology of system being simulated. 

734 

735 units : dict of str : str, optional 

736 Mapping of trajectory field names to string specs 

737 for units. 

738 

739 sparse_fields : list of str, optional 

740 List of trajectory fields that should be initialized as sparse. 

741 

742 feature_shapes : dict of str : shape_spec, optional 

743 Mapping of trajectory fields to their shape spec for initialization. 

744 

745 feature_dtypes : dict of str : dtype_spec, optional 

746 Mapping of trajectory fields to their shape spec for initialization. 

747 

748 n_dims : int, default: 3 

749 Set the number of spatial dimensions for the default 

750 positions trajectory field. 

751 

752 alt_reps : dict of str : list of int, optional 

753 Specifies that there will be 'alt_reps' of positions each 

754 named by the keys of this mapping and containing the 

755 indices in each value list. 

756 

757 main_rep_idxs : list of int, optional 

758 The indices of atom positions to save as the main 'positions' 

759 trajectory field. Defaults to all atoms. 

760 

761 expert_mode : bool 

762 If True no initialization is performed other than the 

763 setting of the filename. Useful mainly for debugging. 

764 

765 Raises 

766 ------ 

767 

768 AssertionError 

769 If the mode is not one of the supported mode specs. 

770 

771 AssertionError 

772 If a topology is not given for a creation mode. 

773 

774 Warns 

775 ----- 

776 

777 If initialization data was given but the file was opened in a read mode. 

778 

779 """ 

780 

781 self._filename = filename 

782 self._swmr_mode = swmr_mode 

783 

784 if expert_mode is True: 

785 self._h5 = None 

786 self._wepy_mode = None 

787 self._h5py_mode = None 

788 self.closed = None 

789 

790 # terminate the constructor here 

791 return None 

792 

793 assert mode in self.MODES, \ 

794 "mode must be either one of: {}".format(', '.join(self.MODES)) 

795 

796 # the top level mode enforced by wepy.hdf5 

797 self._wepy_mode = mode 

798 

799 # the lower level h5py mode. THis was originally different to 

800 # accomodate different modes at teh wepy level for 

801 # concatenation. I will leave these separate because this is 

802 # used elsewhere and could be a feature in the future. 

803 self._h5py_mode = mode 

804 

805 # Temporary metadata: used to initialize the object but not 

806 # used after that 

807 

808 self._topology = topology 

809 self._units = units 

810 self._n_dims = n_dims 

811 self._n_coords = None 

812 

813 # set hidden feature shapes and dtype, which are only 

814 # referenced if needed when trajectories are created. These 

815 # will be saved in the settings section in the actual HDF5 

816 # file 

817 self._field_feature_shapes_kwarg = feature_shapes 

818 self._field_feature_dtypes_kwarg = feature_dtypes 

819 self._field_feature_dtypes = None 

820 self._field_feature_shapes = None 

821 

822 # save the sparse fields as a private variable for use in the 

823 # create constructor 

824 if sparse_fields is None: 

825 self._sparse_fields = [] 

826 else: 

827 self._sparse_fields = sparse_fields 

828 

829 # if we specify an atom subset of the main POSITIONS field 

830 # we must save them 

831 self._main_rep_idxs = main_rep_idxs 

832 

833 # a dictionary specifying other alt_reps to be saved 

834 if alt_reps is not None: 

835 self._alt_reps = alt_reps 

836 # all alt_reps are sparse 

837 alt_rep_keys = ['{}/{}'.format(ALT_REPS, key) for key in self._alt_reps.keys()] 

838 self._sparse_fields.extend(alt_rep_keys) 

839 else: 

840 self._alt_reps = {} 

841 

842 

843 # open the file and then run the different constructors based 

844 # on the mode 

845 with h5py.File(filename, mode=self._h5py_mode, 

846 libver=H5PY_LIBVER, swmr=self._swmr_mode) as h5: 

847 self._h5 = h5 

848 

849 # set SWMR mode if asked for if we are in write mode also 

850 if self._swmr_mode is True and mode in self.WRITE_MODES: 

851 self._h5.swmr_mode = swmr_mode 

852 

853 # create file mode: 'w' will create a new file or overwrite, 

854 # 'w-' and 'x' will not overwrite but will create a new file 

855 if self._wepy_mode in ['w', 'w-', 'x']: 

856 self._create_init() 

857 

858 # read/write mode: in this mode we do not completely overwrite 

859 # the old file and start again but rather write over top of 

860 # values if requested 

861 elif self._wepy_mode in ['r+']: 

862 self._read_write_init() 

863 

864 # add mode: read/write create if doesn't exist 

865 elif self._wepy_mode in ['a']: 

866 if osp.exists(self._filename): 

867 self._read_write_init() 

868 else: 

869 self._create_init() 

870 

871 # read only mode 

872 elif self._wepy_mode == 'r': 

873 

874 # if any data was given, warn the user 

875 if any([kwarg is not None for kwarg in 

876 [topology, units, sparse_fields, 

877 feature_shapes, feature_dtypes, 

878 n_dims, alt_reps, main_rep_idxs]]): 

879 warn("Data was given but opening in read-only mode", RuntimeWarning) 

880 

881 # then run the initialization process 

882 self._read_init() 

883 

884 # flush the buffers 

885 self._h5.flush() 

886 

887 # set the h5py mode to the value in the actual h5py.File 

888 # object after creation 

889 self._h5py_mode = self._h5.mode 

890 

891 # get rid of the temporary variables 

892 del self._topology 

893 del self._units 

894 del self._n_dims 

895 del self._n_coords 

896 del self._field_feature_shapes_kwarg 

897 del self._field_feature_dtypes_kwarg 

898 del self._field_feature_shapes 

899 del self._field_feature_dtypes 

900 del self._sparse_fields 

901 del self._main_rep_idxs 

902 del self._alt_reps 

903 

904 # variable to reflect if it is closed or not, should be closed 

905 # after initialization 

906 self.closed = True 

907 

908 # end of the constructor 

909 return None 

910 

911 # TODO is this right? shouldn't we actually delete the data then close 

912 def __del__(self): 

913 self.close() 

914 

915 # context manager methods 

916 

917 def __enter__(self): 

918 self.open() 

919 # self._h5 = h5py.File(self._filename, 

920 # libver=H5PY_LIBVER, swmr=self._swmr_mode) 

921 # self.closed = False 

922 return self 

923 

924 def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_value, exc_tb): 

925 self.close() 

926 

927 @property 

928 def swmr_mode(self): 

929 return self._swmr_mode 

930 

931 @swmr_mode.setter 

932 def swmr_mode(self, val): 

933 self._swmr_mode = val 

934 

935

937 

938 #### hidden methods (_method_name) 

939 

940 ### constructors 

941 def _create_init(self): 

942 """Creation mode constructor. 

943 

944 Completely overwrite the data in the file. Reinitialize the values 

945 and set with the new ones if given. 

946 """ 

947 

948 assert self._topology is not None, \ 

949 "Topology must be given for a creation constructor" 

950 

951 # initialize the runs group 

952 runs_grp = self._h5.create_group(RUNS) 

953 

954 # initialize the settings group 

955 settings_grp = self._h5.create_group(SETTINGS) 

956 

957 # create the topology dataset 

958 self._h5.create_dataset(TOPOLOGY, data=self._topology) 

959 

960 # sparse fields 

961 if self._sparse_fields is not None: 

962 

963 # make a dataset for the sparse fields allowed. this requires 

964 # a 'special' datatype for variable length strings. This is 

965 # supported by HDF5 but not numpy. 

966 vlen_str_dt = h5py.special_dtype(vlen=str) 

967 

968 # create the dataset with empty values for the length of the 

969 # sparse fields given 

970 sparse_fields_ds = settings_grp.create_dataset(SPARSE_FIELDS, 

971 (len(self._sparse_fields),), 

972 dtype=vlen_str_dt, 

973 maxshape=(None,)) 

974 

975 # set the flags 

976 for i, sparse_field in enumerate(self._sparse_fields): 

977 sparse_fields_ds[i] = sparse_field 

978 

979 

980 # field feature shapes and dtypes 

981 

982 # initialize to the defaults, this gives values to 

983 # self._n_coords, and self.field_feature_dtypes, and 

984 # self.field_feature_shapes 

985 self._set_default_init_field_attributes(n_dims=self._n_dims) 

986 

987 # save the number of dimensions and number of atoms in settings 

988 settings_grp.create_dataset(N_DIMS_STR, data=np.array(self._n_dims)) 

989 settings_grp.create_dataset(N_ATOMS, data=np.array(self._n_coords)) 

990 

991 # the main rep atom idxs 

992 settings_grp.create_dataset(MAIN_REP_IDXS, data=self._main_rep_idxs, dtype=np.int) 

993 

994 # alt_reps settings 

995 alt_reps_idxs_grp = settings_grp.create_group(ALT_REPS_IDXS) 

996 for alt_rep_name, idxs in self._alt_reps.items(): 

997 alt_reps_idxs_grp.create_dataset(alt_rep_name, data=idxs, dtype=np.int) 

998 

999 # if both feature shapes and dtypes were specified overwrite 

1000 # (or initialize if not set by defaults) the defaults 

1001 if (self._field_feature_shapes_kwarg is not None) and\ 

1002 (self._field_feature_dtypes_kwarg is not None): 

1003 

1004 self._field_feature_shapes.update(self._field_feature_shapes_kwarg) 

1005 self._field_feature_dtypes.update(self._field_feature_dtypes_kwarg) 

1006 

1007 # any sparse field with unspecified shape and dtype must be 

1008 # set to None so that it will be set at runtime 

1009 for sparse_field in self.sparse_fields: 

1010 if (not sparse_field in self._field_feature_shapes) or \ 

1011 (not sparse_field in self._field_feature_dtypes): 

1012 self._field_feature_shapes[sparse_field] = None 

1013 self._field_feature_dtypes[sparse_field] = None 

1014 

1015 

1016 # save the field feature shapes and dtypes in the settings group 

1017 shapes_grp = settings_grp.create_group(FIELD_FEATURE_SHAPES_STR) 

1018 for field_path, field_shape in self._field_feature_shapes.items(): 

1019 if field_shape is None: 

1020 # set it as a dimensionless array of NaN 

1021 field_shape = np.array(np.nan) 

1022 

1023 shapes_grp.create_dataset(field_path, data=field_shape) 

1024 

1025 dtypes_grp = settings_grp.create_group(FIELD_FEATURE_DTYPES_STR) 

1026 for field_path, field_dtype in self._field_feature_dtypes.items(): 

1027 if field_dtype is None: 

1028 dt_str = NONE_STR 

1029 else: 

1030 # make a json string of the datatype that can be read 

1031 # in again, we call np.dtype again because there is no 

1032 # np.float.descr attribute 

1033 dt_str = json.dumps(np.dtype(field_dtype).descr) 

1034 

1035 dtypes_grp.create_dataset(field_path, data=dt_str) 

1036 

1037 # initialize the units group 

1038 unit_grp = self._h5.create_group(UNITS) 

1039 

1040 # if units were not given set them all to None 

1041 if self._units is None: 

1042 self._units = {} 

1043 for field_path in self._field_feature_shapes.keys(): 

1044 self._units[field_path] = None 

1045 

1046 # set the units 

1047 for field_path, unit_value in self._units.items(): 

1048 

1049 # ignore the field if not given 

1050 if unit_value is None: 

1051 continue 

1052 

1053 unit_path = '{}/{}'.format(UNITS, field_path) 

1054 

1055 unit_grp.create_dataset(unit_path, data=unit_value) 

1056 

1057 

1058 # create the group for the run data records 

1059 records_grp = settings_grp.create_group(RECORD_FIELDS) 

1060 

1061 # create a dataset for the continuation run tuples 

1062 # (continuation_run, base_run), where the first element 

1063 # of the new run that is continuing the run in the second 

1064 # position 

1065 self._init_continuations() 

1066 

1067 def _read_write_init(self): 

1068 """Read-write mode constructor.""" 

1069 

1070 self._read_init() 

1071 

1072 def _add_init(self): 

1073 """The addition mode constructor. 

1074 

1075 Create the dataset if it doesn't exist and put it in r+ mode, 

1076 otherwise, just open in r+ mode. 

1077 

1078 """ 

1079 

1080 if not any(self._exist_flags): 

1081 self._create_init() 

1082 else: 

1083 self._read_write_init() 

1084 

1085 def _read_init(self): 

1086 """Read mode constructor.""" 

1087 

1088 pass 

1089 

1090 def _set_default_init_field_attributes(self, n_dims=None): 

1091 """Sets the feature_shapes and feature_dtypes to be the default for 

1092 this module. These will be used to initialize field datasets when no 

1093 given during construction (i.e. for sparse values) 

1094 

1095 Parameters 

1096 ---------- 

1097 n_dims : int 

1098 

1099 """ 

1100 

1101 # we use the module defaults for the datasets to initialize them 

1102 field_feature_shapes = dict(FIELD_FEATURE_SHAPES) 

1103 field_feature_dtypes = dict(FIELD_FEATURE_DTYPES) 

1104 

1105 

1106 # get the number of coordinates of positions. If there is a 

1107 # main_reps then we have to set the number of atoms to that, 

1108 # if not we count the number of atoms in the topology 

1109 if self._main_rep_idxs is None: 

1110 self._n_coords = json_top_atom_count(self.topology) 

1111 self._main_rep_idxs = list(range(self._n_coords)) 

1112 else: 

1113 self._n_coords = len(self._main_rep_idxs) 

1114 

1115 # get the number of dimensions as a default 

1116 if n_dims is None: 

1117 self._n_dims = N_DIMS 

1118 

1119 # feature shapes for positions and positions-like fields are 

1120 # not known at the module level due to different number of 

1121 # coordinates (number of atoms) and number of dimensions 

1122 # (default 3 spatial). We set them now that we know this 

1123 # information. 

1124 # add the postitions shape 

1125 field_feature_shapes[POSITIONS] = (self._n_coords, self._n_dims) 

1126 # add the positions-like field shapes (velocities and forces) as the same 

1127 for poslike_field in POSITIONS_LIKE_FIELDS: 

1128 field_feature_shapes[poslike_field] = (self._n_coords, self._n_dims) 

1129 

1130 # set the attributes 

1131 self._field_feature_shapes = field_feature_shapes 

1132 self._field_feature_dtypes = field_feature_dtypes 

1133 

1134 def _get_field_path_grp(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path): 

1135 """Given a field path for the trajectory returns the group the field's 

1136 dataset goes in and the key for the field name in that group. 

1137 

1138 The field path for a simple field is just the name of the 

1139 field and for a compound field it is the compound field group 

1140 name with the subfield separated by a '/' like 

1141 'observables/observable1' where 'observables' is the compound 

1142 field group and 'observable1' is the subfield name. 

1143 

1144 Parameters 

1145 ---------- 

1146 run_idx : int 

1147 traj_idx : int 

1148 field_path : str 

1149 

1150 Returns 

1151 ------- 

1152 group : h5py.Group 

1153 

1154 field_name : str 

1155 

1156 """ 

1157 

1158 # check if it is compound 

1159 if '/' in field_path: 

1160 # split it 

1161 grp_name, field_name = field_path.split('/') 

1162 # get the hdf5 group 

1163 grp = self.h5['{}/{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx, grp_name)] 

1164 # its simple so just return the root group and the original path 

1165 else: 

1166 grp = self.h5 

1167 field_name = field_path 

1168 

1169 return grp, field_name 

1170 

1171 def _init_continuations(self): 

1172 """This will either create a dataset in the settings for the 

1173 continuations or if continuations already exist it will reinitialize 

1174 them and delete the data that exists there. 

1175 

1176 Returns 

1177 ------- 

1178 continuation_dset : h5py.Dataset 

1179 

1180 """ 

1181 

1182 # if the continuations dset already exists we reinitialize the 

1183 # data 

1184 if CONTINUATIONS in self.settings_grp: 

1185 cont_dset = self.settings_grp[CONTINUATIONS] 

1186 cont_dset.resize( (0,2) ) 

1187 

1188 # otherwise we just create the data 

1189 else: 

1190 cont_dset = self.settings_grp.create_dataset(CONTINUATIONS, shape=(0,2), dtype=np.int, 

1191 maxshape=(None, 2)) 

1192 

1193 return cont_dset

1195 

1196 def _add_run_init(self, run_idx, continue_run=None): 

1197 """Routines for creating a run includes updating and setting object 

1198 global variables, increasing the counter for the number of runs. 

1199 

1200 Parameters 

1201 ---------- 

1202 run_idx : int 

1203 

1204 continue_run : int 

1205 Index of the run to continue. 

1206 

1207 """ 

1208 

1209 

1210 # add the run idx as metadata in the run group 

1211 self._h5['{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx)].attrs[RUN_IDX] = run_idx 

1212 

1213 # if this is continuing another run add the tuple (this_run, 

1214 # continues_run) to the continutations settings 

1215 if continue_run is not None: 

1216 

1217 self.add_continuation(run_idx, continue_run) 

1218 

1219 def _add_init_walkers(self, init_walkers_grp, init_walkers): 

1220 """Adds the run field group for the initial walkers. 

1221 

1222 Parameters 

1223 ---------- 

1224 init_walkers_grp : h5py.Group 

1225 The group to add the walker data to. 

1226 init_walkers : list of objects implementing the Walker interface 

1227 The walkers to save in the group 

1228 

1229 """ 

1230 

1231 # add the initial walkers to the group by essentially making 

1232 # new trajectories here that will only have one frame 

1233 for walker_idx, walker in enumerate(init_walkers): 

1234 walker_grp = init_walkers_grp.create_group(str(walker_idx)) 

1235 

1236 # weights 

1237 

1238 # get the weight from the walker and make a feature array of it 

1239 weights = np.array([[walker.weight]]) 

1240 

1241 # then create the dataset and set it 

1242 walker_grp.create_dataset(WEIGHTS, data=weights) 

1243 

1244 # state fields data 

1245 for field_key, field_value in walker.state.dict().items(): 

1246 

1247 # values may be None, just ignore them 

1248 if field_value is not None: 

1249 # just create the dataset by making it a feature array 

1250 # (wrapping it in another list) 

1251 walker_grp.create_dataset(field_key, data=np.array([field_value])) 

1252 

1253 

1254 def _init_run_sporadic_record_grp(self, run_idx, run_record_key, fields): 

1255 """Initialize a sporadic record group for a run. 

1256 

1257 Parameters 

1258 ---------- 

1259 run_idx : int 

1260 

1261 run_record_key : str 

1262 The record group name. 

1263 fields : list of field specs 

1264 Each field spec is a 3-tuple of 

1265 (field_name : str, field_shape : shape_spec, field_dtype : dtype_spec) 

1266 

1267 Returns 

1268 ------- 

1269 record_group : h5py.Group 

1270 

1271 """ 

1272 

1273 # create the group 

1274 run_grp = self.run(run_idx) 

1275 record_grp = run_grp.create_group(run_record_key) 

1276 

1277 # initialize the cycles dataset that maps when the records 

1278 # were recorded 

1279 record_grp.create_dataset(CYCLE_IDXS, (0,), dtype=np.int, 

1280 maxshape=(None,)) 

1281 

1282 # for each field simply create the dataset 

1283 for field_name, field_shape, field_dtype in fields: 

1284 

1285 # initialize this field 

1286 self._init_run_records_field(run_idx, run_record_key, 

1287 field_name, field_shape, field_dtype) 

1288 

1289 return record_grp 

1290 

1291 

1292 def _init_run_continual_record_grp(self, run_idx, run_record_key, fields): 

1293 """Initialize a continual record group for a run. 

1294 

1295 Parameters 

1296 ---------- 

1297 run_idx : int 

1298 

1299 run_record_key : str 

1300 The record group name. 

1301 fields : list of field specs 

1302 Each field spec is a 3-tuple of 

1303 (field_name : str, field_shape : shape_spec, field_dtype : dtype_spec) 

1304 

1305 Returns 

1306 ------- 

1307 record_group : h5py.Group 

1308 

1309 """ 

1310 

1311 # create the group 

1312 run_grp = self.run(run_idx) 

1313 record_grp = run_grp.create_group(run_record_key) 

1314 

1315 # for each field simply create the dataset 

1316 for field_name, field_shape, field_dtype in fields: 

1317 

1318 self._init_run_records_field(run_idx, run_record_key, 

1319 field_name, field_shape, field_dtype) 

1320 

1321 return record_grp 

1322 

1323 def _init_run_records_field(self, run_idx, run_record_key, 

1324 field_name, field_shape, field_dtype): 

1325 """Initialize a single field for a run record group. 

1326 

1327 Parameters 

1328 ---------- 

1329 run_idx : int 

1330 

1331 run_record_key : str 

1332 The name of the record group. 

1333 field_name : str 

1334 The name of the field in the record group. 

1335 field_shape : tuple of int 

1336 The shape of the dataset for the field. 

1337 field_dtype : dtype_spec 

1338 An h5py recognized data type. 

1339 

1340 Returns 

1341 ------- 

1342 dataset : h5py.Dataset 

1343 

1344 """ 

1345 

1346 record_grp = self.run(run_idx)[run_record_key] 

1347 

1348 # check if it is variable length 

1349 if field_shape is Ellipsis: 

1350 # make a special dtype that allows it to be 

1351 # variable length 

1352 vlen_dt = h5py.special_dtype(vlen=field_dtype) 

1353 

1354 # this is only allowed to be a single dimension 

1355 # since no real shape was given 

1356 dset = record_grp.create_dataset(field_name, (0,), dtype=vlen_dt, 

1357 maxshape=(None,)) 

1358 

1359 # its not just make it normally 

1360 else: 

1361 # create the group 

1362 dset = record_grp.create_dataset(field_name, (0, *field_shape), dtype=field_dtype, 

1363 maxshape=(None, *field_shape)) 

1364 

1365 return dset 

1366 

1367 def _is_sporadic_records(self, run_record_key): 

1368 """Tests whether a record group is sporadic or not. 

1369 

1370 Parameters 

1371 ---------- 

1372 run_record_key : str 

1373 Record group name. 

1374 

1375 Returns 

1376 ------- 

1377 is_sporadic : bool 

1378 True if the record group is sporadic False if not. 

1379 

1380 """ 

1381 

1382 # assume it is continual and check if it is in the sporadic groups 

1383 if run_record_key in SPORADIC_RECORDS: 

1384 return True 

1385 else: 

1386 return False 

1387 

1388 def _init_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, feature_shape, dtype): 

1389 """Initialize a trajectory field. 

1390 

1391 Initialize a data field in the trajectory to be empty but 

1392 resizeable. 

1393 

1394 Parameters 

1395 ---------- 

1396 run_idx : int 

1397 traj_idx : int 

1398 field_path : str 

1399 Field name specification. 

1400 feature_shape : shape_spec 

1401 Specification of shape of a feature vector of the field. 

1402 dtype : dtype_spec 

1403 Specification of the feature vector datatype. 

1404 

1405 """ 

1406 

1407 # check whether this is a sparse field and create it 

1408 # appropriately 

1409 if field_path in self.sparse_fields: 

1410 # it is a sparse field 

1411 self._init_sparse_traj_field(run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, feature_shape, dtype) 

1412 else: 

1413 # it is not a sparse field (AKA simple) 

1414 self._init_contiguous_traj_field(run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, feature_shape, dtype) 

1415 

1416 def _init_contiguous_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, shape, dtype): 

1417 """Initialize a contiguous (non-sparse) trajectory field. 

1418 

1419 Parameters 

1420 ---------- 

1421 run_idx : int 

1422 traj_idx : int 

1423 field_path : str 

1424 Field name specification. 

1425 feature_shape : tuple of int 

1426 Shape of the feature vector of the field. 

1427 dtype : dtype_spec 

1428 H5py recognized datatype 

1429 

1430 """ 

1431 

1432 traj_grp = self._h5['{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx)] 

1433 

1434 # create the empty dataset in the correct group, setting 

1435 # maxshape so it can be resized for new feature vectors to be added 

1436 traj_grp.create_dataset(field_path, (0, *[0 for i in shape]), dtype=dtype, 

1437 maxshape=(None, *shape)) 

1438 

1439 

1440 def _init_sparse_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, shape, dtype): 

1441 """ 

1442 

1443 Parameters 

1444 ---------- 

1445 run_idx : int 

1446 traj_idx : int 

1447 field_path : str 

1448 Field name specification. 

1449 feature_shape : shape_spec 

1450 Specification for the shape of the feature. 

1451 dtype : dtype_spec 

1452 Specification for the dtype of the feature. 

1453 

1454 """ 

1455 

1456 traj_grp = self._h5['{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx)] 

1457 

1458 # check to see that neither the shape and dtype are 

1459 # None which indicates it is a runtime defined value and 

1460 # should be ignored here 

1461 if (shape is None) or (dtype is None): 

1462 # do nothing 

1463 pass 

1464 else: 

1465 

1466 # only create the group if you are going to add the 

1467 # datasets so the extend function can know if it has been 

1468 # properly initialized easier 

1469 sparse_grp = traj_grp.create_group(field_path) 

1470 

1471 # create the dataset for the feature data 

1472 sparse_grp.create_dataset(DATA, (0, *[0 for i in shape]), dtype=dtype, 

1473 maxshape=(None, *shape)) 

1474 

1475 # create the dataset for the sparse indices 

1476 sparse_grp.create_dataset(SPARSE_IDXS, (0,), dtype=np.int, maxshape=(None,)) 

1477 

1478 

1479 def _init_traj_fields(self, run_idx, traj_idx, 

1480 field_paths, field_feature_shapes, field_feature_dtypes): 

1481 """Initialize a number of fields for a trajectory. 

1482 

1483 Parameters 

1484 ---------- 

1485 run_idx : int 

1486 traj_idx : int 

1487 field_paths : list of str 

1488 List of field names. 

1489 field_feature_shapes : list of shape_specs 

1490 field_feature_dtypes : list of dtype_specs 

1491 

1492 """ 

1493 for i, field_path in enumerate(field_paths): 

1494 self._init_traj_field(run_idx, traj_idx, 

1495 field_path, field_feature_shapes[i], field_feature_dtypes[i]) 

1496 

1497 def _add_traj_field_data(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, field_data, sparse_idxs=None): 

1498 """Add a trajectory field to a trajectory. 

1499 

1500 If the sparse indices are given the field will be created as a 

1501 sparse field otherwise a normal one. 

1502 

1503 Parameters 

1504 ---------- 

1505 run_idx : int 

1506 

1507 traj_idx : int 

1508 

1509 field_path : str 

1510 Field name. 

1511 

1512 field_data : numpy.array 

1513 The data array to set for the field. 

1514 

1515 sparse_idxs : arraylike of int of shape (1,) 

1516 List of cycle indices that the data corresponds to. 

1517 

1518 """ 

1519 

1520 # get the traj group 

1521 traj_grp = self._h5['{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx)] 

1522 

1523 # if it is a sparse dataset we need to add the data and add 

1524 # the idxs in a group 

1525 if sparse_idxs is None: 

1526 

1527 # first require that the dataset exist and is exactly the 

1528 # same as the one that already exists (if indeed it 

1529 # does). If it doesn't raise a specific error letting the 

1530 # user know that they will have to delete the dataset if 

1531 # they want to change it to something else 

1532 try: 

1533 dset = traj_grp.require_dataset(field_path, shape=field_data.shape, dtype=field_data.dtype, 

1534 exact=True, 

1535 maxshape=(None, *field_data.shape[1:])) 

1536 except TypeError: 

1537 raise TypeError("For changing the contents of a trajectory field it must be the same shape and dtype.") 

1538 

1539 # if that succeeds then go ahead and set the data to the 

1540 # dataset (overwriting if it is still there) 

1541 dset[...] = field_data 

1542 

1543 else: 

1544 sparse_grp = traj_grp.create_group(field_path) 

1545 # add the data to this group 

1546 sparse_grp.create_dataset(DATA, data=field_data, 

1547 maxshape=(None, *field_data.shape[1:])) 

1548 # add the sparse idxs 

1549 sparse_grp.create_dataset(SPARSE_IDXS, data=sparse_idxs, 

1550 maxshape=(None,)) 

1551 

1552 def _extend_contiguous_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, field_data): 

1553 """Add multiple new frames worth of data to the end of an existing 

1554 contiguous (non-sparse)trajectory field. 

1555 

1556 Parameters 

1557 ---------- 

1558 run_idx : int 

1559 traj_idx : int 

1560 field_path : str 

1561 Field name 

1562 field_data : numpy.array 

1563 The frames of data to add. 

1564 

1565 """ 

1566 

1567 traj_grp = self.h5['{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx)] 

1568 field = traj_grp[field_path] 

1569 

1570 # make sure this is a feature vector 

1571 assert len(field_data.shape) > 1, \ 

1572 "field_data must be a feature vector with the same number of dimensions as the number" 

1573 

1574 # of datase new frames 

1575 n_new_frames = field_data.shape[0] 

1576 

1577 # check the field to make sure it is not empty 

1578 if all([i == 0 for i in field.shape]): 

1579 

1580 # check the feature shape against the maxshape which gives 

1581 # the feature dimensions for an empty dataset 

1582 assert field_data.shape[1:] == field.maxshape[1:], \ 

1583 "field feature dimensions must be the same, i.e. all but the first dimension" 

1584 

1585 # if it is empty resize it to make an array the size of 

1586 # the new field_data with the maxshape for the feature 

1587 # dimensions 

1588 feature_dims = field.maxshape[1:] 

1589 field.resize( (n_new_frames, *feature_dims) ) 

1590 

1591 # set the new data to this 

1592 field[0:, ...] = field_data 

1593 

1594 else: 

1595 # make sure the new data has the right dimensions against 

1596 # the shape it already has 

1597 assert field_data.shape[1:] == field.shape[1:], \ 

1598 "field feature dimensions must be the same, i.e. all but the first dimension" 

1599 

1600 

1601 # append to the dataset on the first dimension, keeping the 

1602 # others the same, these must be feature vectors and therefore 

1603 # must exist 

1604 field.resize( (field.shape[0] + n_new_frames, *field.shape[1:]) ) 

1605 # add the new data 

1606 field[-n_new_frames:, ...] = field_data 

1607 

1608 def _extend_sparse_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, values, sparse_idxs): 

1609 """Add multiple new frames worth of data to the end of an existing 

1610 contiguous (non-sparse)trajectory field. 

1611 

1612 Parameters 

1613 ---------- 

1614 run_idx : int 

1615 traj_idx : int 

1616 field_path : str 

1617 Field name 

1618 values : numpy.array 

1619 The frames of data to add. 

1620 sparse_idxs : list of int 

1621 The cycle indices the values correspond to. 

1622 

1623 """ 

1624 

1625 field = self.h5['{}/{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx, field_path)] 

1626 

1627 field_data = field[DATA] 

1628 field_sparse_idxs = field[SPARSE_IDXS] 

1629 

1630 # number of new frames 

1631 n_new_frames = values.shape[0] 

1632 

1633 # if this sparse_field has been initialized empty we need to resize 

1634 if all([i == 0 for i in field_data.shape]): 

1635 

1636 

1637 # check the feature shape against the maxshape which gives 

1638 # the feature dimensions for an empty dataset 

1639 assert values.shape[1:] == field_data.maxshape[1:], \ 

1640 "input value features have shape {}, expected {}".format( 

1641 values.shape[1:], field_data.maxshape[1:]) 

1642 

1643 # if it is empty resize it to make an array the size of 

1644 # the new values with the maxshape for the feature 

1645 # dimensions 

1646 feature_dims = field_data.maxshape[1:] 

1647 field_data.resize( (n_new_frames, *feature_dims) ) 

1648 

1649 # set the new data to this 

1650 field_data[0:, ...] = values 

1651 

1652 else: 

1653 

1654 # make sure the new data has the right dimensions 

1655 assert values.shape[1:] == field_data.shape[1:], \ 

1656 "field feature dimensions must be the same, i.e. all but the first dimension" 

1657 

1658 # append to the dataset on the first dimension, keeping the 

1659 # others the same, these must be feature vectors and therefore 

1660 # must exist 

1661 field_data.resize( (field_data.shape[0] + n_new_frames, *field_data.shape[1:]) ) 

1662 # add the new data 

1663 field_data[-n_new_frames:, ...] = values 

1664 

1665 # add the sparse idxs in the same way 

1666 field_sparse_idxs.resize( (field_sparse_idxs.shape[0] + n_new_frames, 

1667 *field_sparse_idxs.shape[1:]) ) 

1668 # add the new data 

1669 field_sparse_idxs[-n_new_frames:, ...] = sparse_idxs 

1670 

1671 def _add_sparse_field_flag(self, field_path): 

1672 """Register a trajectory field as sparse in the header settings. 

1673 

1674 Parameters 

1675 ---------- 

1676 field_path : str 

1677 Name of the trajectory field you want to flag as sparse 

1678 

1679 """ 

1680 

1681 sparse_fields_ds = self._h5['{}/{}'.format(SETTINGS, SPARSE_FIELDS)] 

1682 

1683 # make sure it isn't already in the sparse_fields 

1684 if field_path in sparse_fields_ds[:]: 

1685 warn("sparse field {} already a sparse field, ignoring".format(field_path)) 

1686 

1687 sparse_fields_ds.resize( (sparse_fields_ds.shape[0] + 1,) ) 

1688 sparse_fields_ds[sparse_fields_ds.shape[0] - 1] = field_path 

1689 

1690 def _add_field_feature_shape(self, field_path, field_feature_shape): 

1691 """Add the shape to the header settings for a trajectory field. 

1692 

1693 Parameters 

1694 ---------- 

1695 field_path : str 

1696 The name of the trajectory field you want to set for. 

1697 field_feature_shape : shape_spec 

1698 The shape spec to serialize as a dataset. 

1699 

1700 """ 

1701 shapes_grp = self._h5['{}/{}'.format(SETTINGS, FIELD_FEATURE_SHAPES_STR)] 

1702 shapes_grp.create_dataset(field_path, data=np.array(field_feature_shape)) 

1703 

1704 def _add_field_feature_dtype(self, field_path, field_feature_dtype): 

1705 """Add the data type to the header settings for a trajectory field. 

1706 

1707 Parameters 

1708 ---------- 

1709 field_path : str 

1710 The name of the trajectory field you want to set for. 

1711 field_feature_dtype : dtype_spec 

1712 The dtype spec to serialize as a dataset. 

1713 

1714 """ 

1715 feature_dtype_str = json.dumps(field_feature_dtype.descr) 

1716 dtypes_grp = self._h5['{}/{}'.format(SETTINGS, FIELD_FEATURE_DTYPES_STR)] 

1717 dtypes_grp.create_dataset(field_path, data=feature_dtype_str) 

1718 

1719 

1720 def _set_field_feature_shape(self, field_path, field_feature_shape): 

1721 """Add the trajectory field shape to header settings or set the value. 

1722 

1723 Parameters 

1724 ---------- 

1725 field_path : str 

1726 The name of the trajectory field you want to set for. 

1727 field_feature_shape : shape_spec 

1728 The shape spec to serialize as a dataset. 

1729 

1730 """ 

1731 # check if the field_feature_shape is already set 

1732 if field_path in self.field_feature_shapes: 

1733 # check that the shape was previously saved as "None" as we 

1734 # won't overwrite anything else 

1735 if self.field_feature_shapes[field_path] is None: 

1736 full_path = '{}/{}/{}'.format(SETTINGS, FIELD_FEATURE_SHAPES_STR, field_path) 

1737 # we have to delete the old data and set new data 

1738 del self.h5[full_path] 

1739 self.h5.create_dataset(full_path, data=field_feature_shape) 

1740 else: 

1741 raise AttributeError( 

1742 "Cannot overwrite feature shape for {} with {} because it is {} not {}".format( 

1743 field_path, field_feature_shape, self.field_feature_shapes[field_path], 

1744 NONE_STR)) 

1745 # it was not previously set so we must create then save it 

1746 else: 

1747 self._add_field_feature_shape(field_path, field_feature_shape) 

1748 

1749 def _set_field_feature_dtype(self, field_path, field_feature_dtype): 

1750 """Add the trajectory field dtype to header settings or set the value. 

1751 

1752 Parameters 

1753 ---------- 

1754 field_path : str 

1755 The name of the trajectory field you want to set for. 

1756 field_feature_dtype : dtype_spec 

1757 The dtype spec to serialize as a dataset. 

1758 

1759 """ 

1760 feature_dtype_str = json.dumps(field_feature_dtype.descr) 

1761 # check if the field_feature_dtype is already set 

1762 if field_path in self.field_feature_dtypes: 

1763 # check that the dtype was previously saved as "None" as we 

1764 # won't overwrite anything else 

1765 if self.field_feature_dtypes[field_path] is None: 

1766 full_path = '{}/{}/{}'.format(SETTINGS, FIELD_FEATURE_DTYPES_STR, field_path) 

1767 # we have to delete the old data and set new data 

1768 del self.h5[full_path] 

1769 self.h5.create_dataset(full_path, data=feature_dtype_str) 

1770 else: 

1771 raise AttributeError( 

1772 "Cannot overwrite feature dtype for {} with {} because it is {} not ".format( 

1773 field_path, field_feature_dtype, self.field_feature_dtypes[field_path], 

1774 NONE_STR)) 

1775 # it was not previously set so we must create then save it 

1776 else: 

1777 self._add_field_feature_dtype(field_path, field_feature_dtype) 

1778 

1779 def _extend_run_record_data_field(self, run_idx, run_record_key, 

1780 field_name, field_data): 

1781 """Primitive record append method. 

1782 

1783 Adds data for a single field dataset in a run records group. This 

1784 is done without paying attention to whether it is sporadic or 

1785 continual and is supposed to be only the data write method. 

1786 

1787 Parameters 

1788 ---------- 

1789 run_idx : int 

1790 run_record_key : str 

1791 Name of the record group. 

1792 field_name : str 

1793 Name of the field in the record group to add to. 

1794 field_data : arraylike 

1795 The data to add to the field. 

1796 

1797 """ 

1798 

1799 records_grp = self.h5['{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, run_record_key)] 

1800 field = records_grp[field_name] 

1801 

1802 # make sure this is a feature vector 

1803 assert len(field_data.shape) > 1, \ 

1804 "field_data must be a feature vector with the same number of dimensions as the number" 

1805 

1806 # of datase new frames 

1807 n_new_frames = field_data.shape[0] 

1808 

1809 # check whether it is a variable length record, by getting the 

1810 # record dataset dtype and using the checker to see if it is 

1811 # the vlen special type in h5py 

1812 if h5py.check_dtype(vlen=field.dtype) is not None: 

1813 

1814 # if it is we have to treat it differently, since it 

1815 # cannot be multidimensional 

1816 

1817 # if the dataset has no data in it we need to reshape it 

1818 if all([i == 0 for i in field.shape]): 

1819 # initialize this array 

1820 # if it is empty resize it to make an array the size of 

1821 # the new field_data with the maxshape for the feature 

1822 # dimensions 

1823 field.resize( (n_new_frames,) ) 

1824 

1825 # set the new data to this 

1826 for i, row in enumerate(field_data): 

1827 field[i] = row 

1828 

1829 # otherwise just add the data 

1830 else: 

1831 

1832 # resize the array but it is only of rank because 

1833 # of variable length data 

1834 field.resize( (field.shape[0] + n_new_frames, ) ) 

1835 

1836 # add each row to the newly made space 

1837 for i, row in enumerate(field_data): 

1838 field[(field.shape[0] - 1) + i] = row 

1839 

1840 # if it is not variable length we don't have to treat it 

1841 # differently 

1842 else: 

1843 

1844 # if this is empty we need to reshape the dataset to accomodate data 

1845 if all([i == 0 for i in field.shape]): 

1846 

1847 # check the feature shape against the maxshape which gives 

1848 # the feature dimensions for an empty dataset 

1849 assert field_data.shape[1:] == field.maxshape[1:], \ 

1850 "field feature dimensions must be the same, i.e. all but the first dimension" 

1851 

1852 # if it is empty resize it to make an array the size of 

1853 # the new field_data with the maxshape for the feature 

1854 # dimensions 

1855 feature_dims = field.maxshape[1:] 

1856 field.resize( (n_new_frames, *feature_dims) ) 

1857 

1858 # set the new data to this 

1859 field[0:, ...] = field_data 

1860 

1861 # otherwise just add the data 

1862 else: 

1863 # append to the dataset on the first dimension, keeping the 

1864 # others the same, these must be feature vectors and therefore 

1865 # must exist 

1866 field.resize( (field.shape[0] + n_new_frames, *field.shape[1:]) ) 

1867 # add the new data 

1868 field[-n_new_frames:, ...] = field_data 

1869 

1870 

1871 def _run_record_namedtuple(self, run_record_key): 

1872 """Generate a namedtuple record type for a record group. 

1873 

1874 The class name will be formatted like '{}_Record' where the {} 

1875 will be replaced with the name of the record group. 

1876 

1877 Parameters 

1878 ---------- 

1879 run_record_key : str 

1880 Name of the record group 

1881 

1882 Returns 

1883 ------- 

1884 RecordType : namedtuple 

1885 The record type to generate records for this record group. 

1886 

1887 """ 

1888 

1889 Record = namedtuple('{}_Record'.format(run_record_key), 

1890 [CYCLE_IDX] + self.record_fields[run_record_key]) 

1891 

1892 return Record 

1893 

1894 def _convert_record_field_to_table_column(self, run_idx, run_record_key, record_field): 

1895 """Converts a dataset of feature vectors to more palatable values for 

1896 use in external datasets. 

1897 

1898 For single value feature vectors it unwraps them into single 

1899 values. 

1900 

1901 For 1-D feature vectors it casts them as tuples. 

1902 

1903 Anything of higher rank will raise an error. 

1904 

1905 Parameters 

1906 ---------- 

1907 run_idx : int 

1908 run_record_key : str 

1909 Name of the record group 

1910 record_field : str 

1911 Name of the field of the record group 

1912 

1913 Returns 

1914 ------- 

1915 

1916 record_dset : list 

1917 Table-ified values 

1918 

1919 Raises 

1920 ------ 

1921 

1922 TypeError 

1923 If the field feature vector shape rank is greater than 1. 

1924 

1925 """ 

1926 

1927 # get the field dataset 

1928 rec_grp = self.records_grp(run_idx, run_record_key) 

1929 dset = rec_grp[record_field] 

1930 

1931 # if it is variable length or if it has more than one element 

1932 # cast all elements to tuples 

1933 if h5py.check_dtype(vlen=dset.dtype) is not None: 

1934 rec_dset = [tuple(value) for value in dset[:]] 

1935 

1936 # if it is not variable length make sure it is not more than a 

1937 # 1D feature vector 

1938 elif len(dset.shape) > 2: 

1939 raise TypeError( 

1940 "cannot convert fields with feature vectors more than 1 dimension," 

1941 " was given {} for {}/{}".format( 

1942 dset.shape[1:], run_record_key, record_field)) 

1943 

1944 # if it is only a rank 1 feature vector and it has more than 

1945 # one element make a tuple out of it 

1946 elif dset.shape[1] > 1: 

1947 rec_dset = [tuple(value) for value in dset[:]] 

1948 

1949 # otherwise just get the single value instead of keeping it as 

1950 # a single valued feature vector 

1951 else: 

1952 rec_dset = [value[0] for value in dset[:]] 

1953 

1954 return rec_dset 

1955 

1956 def _convert_record_fields_to_table_columns(self, run_idx, run_record_key): 

1957 """Convert record group data to truncated namedtuple records. 

1958 

1959 This uses the specified record fields from the header settings 

1960 to choose which record group fields to apply this to. 

1961 

1962 Does no checking to make sure the fields are 

1963 "table-ifiable". If a field is not it will raise a TypeError. 

1964 

1965 Parameters 

1966 ---------- 

1967 run_idx : int 

1968 run_record_key : str 

1969 The name of the record group 

1970 

1971 Returns 

1972 ------- 

1973 table_fields : dict of str : list 

1974 Mapping of the record group field to the table-ified values. 

1975 

1976 """ 

1977 

1978 fields = {} 

1979 for record_field in self.record_fields[run_record_key]: 

1980 fields[record_field] = self._convert_record_field_to_table_column( 

1981 run_idx, run_record_key, record_field) 

1982 

1983 return fields 

1984 

1985 def _make_records(self, run_record_key, cycle_idxs, fields): 

1986 """Generate a list of proper (nametuple) records for a record group. 

1987 

1988 Parameters 

1989 ---------- 

1990 run_record_key : str 

1991 Name of the record group 

1992 cycle_idxs : list of int 

1993 The cycle indices you want to get records for. 

1994 fields : list of str 

1995 The fields to make record entries for. 

1996 

1997 Returns 

1998 ------- 

1999 records : list of namedtuple objects 

2000 

2001 """ 

2002 Record = self._run_record_namedtuple(run_record_key) 

2003 

2004 # for each record we make a tuple and yield it 

2005 records = [] 

2006 for record_idx in range(len(cycle_idxs)): 

2007 

2008 # make a record for this cycle 

2009 record_d = {CYCLE_IDX : cycle_idxs[record_idx]} 

2010 for record_field, column in fields.items(): 

2011 datum = column[record_idx] 

2012 record_d[record_field] = datum 

2013 

2014 record = Record(*(record_d[key] for key in Record._fields)) 

2015 

2016 records.append(record) 

2017 

2018 return records 

2019 

2020 def _run_records_sporadic(self, run_idxs, run_record_key): 

2021 """Generate records for a sporadic record group for a multi-run 

2022 contig. 

2023 

2024 If multiple run indices are given assumes that these are a 

2025 contig (e.g. the second run index is a continuation of the 

2026 first and so on). This method is considered low-level and does 

2027 no checking to make sure this is true. 

2028 

2029 The cycle indices of records from "continuation" runs will be 

2030 modified so as the records will be indexed as if they are a 

2031 single run. 

2032 

2033 Uses the record fields settings to decide which fields to use. 

2034 

2035 Parameters 

2036 ---------- 

2037 run_idxs : list of int 

2038 The indices of the runs in the order they are in the contig 

2039 run_record_key : str 

2040 Name of the record group 

2041 

2042 Returns 

2043 ------- 

2044 records : list of namedtuple objects 

2045 

2046 """ 

2047 

2048 # we loop over the run_idxs in the contig and get the fields 

2049 # and cycle idxs for the whole contig 

2050 fields = None 

2051 cycle_idxs = np.array([], dtype=int) 

2052 # keep a cumulative total of the runs cycle idxs 

2053 prev_run_cycle_total = 0 

2054 for run_idx in run_idxs: 

2055 

2056 # get all the value columns from the datasets, and convert 

2057 # them to something amenable to a table 

2058 run_fields = self._convert_record_fields_to_table_columns(run_idx, run_record_key) 

2059 

2060 # we need to concatenate each field to the end of the 

2061 # field in the master dictionary, first we need to 

2062 # initialize it if it isn't already made 

2063 if fields is None: 

2064 # if it isn't initialized we just set it as this first 

2065 # run fields dictionary 

2066 fields = run_fields 

2067 else: 

2068 # if it is already initialized we need to go through 

2069 # each field and concatenate 

2070 for field_name, field_data in run_fields.items(): 

2071 # just add it to the list of fields that will be concatenated later 

2072 fields[field_name].extend(field_data) 

2073 

2074 # get the cycle idxs for this run 

2075 rec_grp = self.records_grp(run_idx, run_record_key) 

2076 run_cycle_idxs = rec_grp[CYCLE_IDXS][:] 

2077 

2078 # add the total number of cycles that came before this run 

2079 # to each of the cycle idxs to get the cycle_idxs in terms 

2080 # of the full contig 

2081 run_contig_cycle_idxs = run_cycle_idxs + prev_run_cycle_total 

2082 

2083 # add these cycle indices to the records for the whole contig 

2084 cycle_idxs = np.hstack( (cycle_idxs, run_contig_cycle_idxs) ) 

2085 

2086 # add the total number of cycle_idxs from this run to the 

2087 # running total 

2088 prev_run_cycle_total += self.num_run_cycles(run_idx) 

2089 

2090 # then make the records from the fields 

2091 records = self._make_records(run_record_key, cycle_idxs, fields) 

2092 

2093 return records 

2094 

2095 def _run_records_continual(self, run_idxs, run_record_key): 

2096 """Generate records for a continual record group for a multi-run 

2097 contig. 

2098 

2099 If multiple run indices are given assumes that these are a 

2100 contig (e.g. the second run index is a continuation of the 

2101 first and so on). This method is considered low-level and does 

2102 no checking to make sure this is true. 

2103 

2104 The cycle indices of records from "continuation" runs will be 

2105 modified so as the records will be indexed as if they are a 

2106 single run. 

2107 

2108 Uses the record fields settings to decide which fields to use. 

2109 

2110 Parameters 

2111 ---------- 

2112 run_idxs : list of int 

2113 The indices of the runs in the order they are in the contig 

2114 run_record_key : str 

2115 Name of the record group 

2116 

2117 Returns 

2118 ------- 

2119 records : list of namedtuple objects 

2120 

2121 """ 

2122 

2123 cycle_idxs = np.array([], dtype=int) 

2124 fields = None 

2125 prev_run_cycle_total = 0 

2126 for run_idx in run_idxs: 

2127 # get all the value columns from the datasets, and convert 

2128 # them to something amenable to a table 

2129 run_fields = self._convert_record_fields_to_table_columns(run_idx, run_record_key) 

2130 

2131 # we need to concatenate each field to the end of the 

2132 # field in the master dictionary, first we need to 

2133 # initialize it if it isn't already made 

2134 if fields is None: 

2135 # if it isn't initialized we just set it as this first 

2136 # run fields dictionary 

2137 fields = run_fields 

2138 else: 

2139 # if it is already initialized we need to go through 

2140 # each field and concatenate 

2141 for field_name, field_data in run_fields.items(): 

2142 # just add it to the list of fields that will be concatenated later 

2143 fields[field_name].extend(field_data) 

2144 

2145 # get one of the fields (if any to iterate over) 

2146 record_fields = self.record_fields[run_record_key] 

2147 main_record_field = record_fields[0] 

2148 

2149 # make the cycle idxs from that 

2150 run_rec_grp = self.records_grp(run_idx, run_record_key) 

2151 run_cycle_idxs = np.array(range(run_rec_grp[main_record_field].shape[0])) 

2152 

2153 # add the total number of cycles that came before this run 

2154 # to each of the cycle idxs to get the cycle_idxs in terms 

2155 # of the full contig 

2156 run_contig_cycle_idxs = run_cycle_idxs + prev_run_cycle_total 

2157 

2158 # add these cycle indices to the records for the whole contig 

2159 cycle_idxs = np.hstack( (cycle_idxs, run_contig_cycle_idxs) ) 

2160 

2161 # add the total number of cycle_idxs from this run to the 

2162 # running total 

2163 prev_run_cycle_total += self.num_run_cycles(run_idx) 

2164 

2165 

2166 # then make the records from the fields 

2167 records = self._make_records(run_record_key, cycle_idxs, fields) 

2168 

2169 return records 

2170 

2171 

2172 def _get_contiguous_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, frames=None): 

2173 """Access actual data for a trajectory field. 

2174 

2175 Parameters 

2176 ---------- 

2177 run_idx : int 

2178 traj_idx : int 

2179 field_path : str 

2180 Trajectory field name to access 

2181 frames : list of int, optional 

2182 The indices of the frames to return if you don't want all of them. 

2183 

2184 Returns 

2185 ------- 

2186 field_data : arraylike 

2187 The data requested for the field. 

2188 

2189 """ 

2190 

2191 full_path = '{}/{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx, field_path) 

2192 

2193 if frames is None: 

2194 field = self._h5[full_path][:] 

2195 else: 

2196 field = self._h5[full_path][list(frames)] 

2197 

2198 return field 

2199 

2200 def _get_sparse_traj_field(self, run_idx, traj_idx, field_path, frames=None, masked=True): 

2201 """Access actual data for a trajectory field. 

2202 

2203 Parameters 

2204 ---------- 

2205 run_idx : int 

2206 traj_idx : int 

2207 field_path : str 

2208 Trajectory field name to access 

2209 

2210 frames : list of int, optional 

2211 The indices of the frames to return if you don't want all of them. 

2212 

2213 masked : bool 

2214 If True returns the array data as numpy masked array, and 

2215 only the available values if False. 

2216 

2217 Returns 

2218 ------- 

2219 field_data : arraylike 

2220 The data requested for the field. 

2221 

2222 """ 

2223 

2224 traj_path = '{}/{}/{}/{}'.format(RUNS, run_idx, TRAJECTORIES, traj_idx) 

2225 traj_grp = self.h5[traj_path] 

2226 field = traj_grp[field_path] 

2227 

2228 n_frames = traj_grp[POSITIONS].shape[0] 

2229 

2230 if frames is None: 

2231 data = field[DATA][:] 

2232 

2233 # if it is to be masked make the masked array 

2234 if masked: 

2235 sparse_idxs = field[SPARSE_IDXS][:] 

2236 

2237 filled_data = np.full( (n_frames, *data.shape[1:]), np.nan) 

2238 filled_data[sparse_idxs] = data 

2239 

2240 mask = np.full( (n_frames, *data.shape[1:]), True) 

2241 mask[sparse_idxs] = False 

2242 

2243 data = np.ma.masked_array(filled_data, mask=mask) 

2244 

2245 else: 

2246 

2247 # get the sparse idxs and the frames to slice from the 

2248 # data 

2249 sparse_idxs = field[SPARSE_IDXS][:] 

2250 

2251 # we get a boolean array of the rows of the data table 

2252 # that we are to slice from 

2253 sparse_frame_idxs = np.argwhere(np.isin(sparse_idxs, frames)) 

2254 

2255 data = field[DATA][list(sparse_frame_idxs)] 

2256 

2257 # if it is to be masked make the masked array 

2258 if masked: 

2259 # the empty arrays the size of the number of requested frames 

2260 filled_data = np.full( (len(frames), *field[DATA].shape[1:]), np.nan) 

2261 mask = np.full( (len(frames), *field[DATA].shape[1:]), True ) 

2262 

2263 # take the data which exists and is part of the frames 

2264 # selection, and put it into the filled data where it is 

2265 # supposed to be 

2266 filled_data[np.isin(frames, sparse_idxs)] = data 

2267 

2268 # unmask the present values 

2269 mask[np.isin(frames, sparse_idxs)] = False 

2270 

2271 data = np.ma.masked_array(filled_data, mask=mask) 

2272 

2273 return data 

2274 

2275 

2276 def _add_run_field(self, run_idx, field_path, data, sparse_idxs=None, 

2277 force=False): 

2278 """Add a trajectory field to all trajectories in a run. 

2279 

2280 By enforcing adding it to all trajectories at one time we 

2281 promote in-run consistency. 

2282 

2283 Parameters 

2284 ---------- 

2285 run_idx : int 

2286 field_path : str 

2287 Name to set the trajectory field as. Can be compound. 

2288 data : arraylike of shape (n_trajectories, n_cycles, feature_vector_shape[0],...) 

2289 The data for all trajectories to be added. 

2290 sparse_idxs : list of int 

2291 If the data you are adding is sparse specify which cycles to apply them to. 

2292 

2293 

2294 If 'force' is turned on, no checking for constraints will be done. 

2295 

2296 """ 

2297 

2298 # check that the data has the correct number of trajectories 

2299 if not force: 

2300 assert len(data) == self.num_run_trajs(run_idx),\ 

2301 "The number of trajectories in data, {}, is different than the number"\ 

2302 "of trajectories in the run, {}.".format(len(data), self.num_run_trajs(run_idx)) 

2303 

2304 # for each trajectory check that the data is compliant 

2305 for traj_idx, traj_data in enumerate(data): 

2306 

2307 if not force: 

2308 # check that the number of frames is not larger than that for the run 

2309 if traj_data.shape[0] > self.num_run_cycles(run_idx): 

2310 raise ValueError("The number of frames in data for traj {} , {}," 

2311 "is larger than the number of frames" 

2312 "for this run, {}.".format( 

2313 traj_idx, data.shape[1], self.num_run_cycles(run_idx))) 

2314 

2315 

2316 # if the number of frames given is the same or less than 

2317 # the number of frames in the run 

2318 elif (traj_data.shape[0] <= self.num_run_cycles(run_idx)): 

2319 

2320 # if sparse idxs were given we check to see there is 

2321 # the right number of them 

2322 # and that they match the number of frames given 

2323 if data.shape[0] != len(sparse_idxs[traj_idx]): 

2324 

2325 raise ValueError("The number of frames provided for traj {}, {}," 

2326 "was less than the total number of frames, {}," 

2327 "but an incorrect number of sparse idxs were supplied, {}."\ 

2328 .format(traj_idx, traj_data.shape[0], 

2329 self.num_run_cycles(run_idx), len(sparse_idxs[traj_idx]))) 

2330 

2331 

2332 # if there were strictly fewer frames given and the 

2333 # sparse idxs were not given we need to raise an error 

2334 elif (traj_data.shape[0] < self.num_run_cycles(run_idx)): 

2335 

2336 raise ValueError("The number of frames provided for traj {}, {}," 

2337 "was less than the total number of frames, {}," 

2338 "but sparse_idxs were not supplied.".format( 

2339 traj_idx, traj_data.shape[0], 

2340 self.num_run_cycles(run_idx))) 

2341 

2342 # add it to each traj 

2343 for i, idx_tup in enumerate(self.run_traj_idx_tuples([run_idx])): 

2344 if sparse_idxs is None: 

2345 self._add_traj_field_data(*idx_tup, field_path, data[i]) 

2346 else: 

2347 self._add_traj_field_data(*idx_tup, field_path, data[i], 

2348 sparse_idxs=sparse_idxs[i]) 

2349 

2350 def _add_field(self, field_path, data, sparse_idxs=None, 

2351 force=False): 

2352 """Add a trajectory field to all runs in a file. 

2353 

2354 Parameters 

2355 ---------- 

2356 field_path : str 

2357 Name of trajectory field 

2358 data : list of arraylike 

2359 Each element of this list corresponds to a single run. The 

2360 elements of which are arraylikes of shape (n_trajectories, 

2361 n_cycles, feature_vector_shape[0],...) for each run. 

2362 sparse_idxs : list of list of int 

2363 The list of cycle indices to set for the sparse fields. If 

2364 None, no trajectories are set as sparse. 

2365 

2366 

2367 """ 

2368 

2369 for i, run_idx in enumerate(self.run_idxs): 

2370 if sparse_idxs is not None: 

2371 self._add_run_field(run_idx, field_path, data[i], sparse_idxs=sparse_idxs[i], 

2372 force=force) 

2373 else: 

2374 self._add_run_field(run_idx, field_path, data[i], 

2375 force=force) 

2376

2388

2391 

2392 mode : str 

2393 Valid mode spec. Opens the HDF5 file in this mode if given 

2394 otherwise uses the existing mode. 

2395 

2396 """ 

2397 

2398 if mode is None: 

2399 mode = self.mode 

2400 

2401 if self.closed: 

2402 

2403 self.set_mode(mode) 

2404 

2405 self._h5 = h5py.File(self._filename, mode, 

2406 libver=H5PY_LIBVER, swmr=self.swmr_mode) 

2407 self.closed = False 

2408 else: 

2409 raise IOError("This file is already open")

2413 if not self.closed: 

2414 self._h5.flush() 

2415 self._h5.close() 

2416 self.closed = True

2645 def bc_grp(self, run_idx):

2647 

2648 Parameters 

2649 ---------- 

2650 run_idx : int 

2651 

2652 Returns 

2653 ------- 

2654 run_record_group : h5py.Group 

2655 

2656 """ 

2657 return self.records_grp(run_idx, BC)
